case_name: B. Seth Champa Lal Ram Swarup

facts.text: Three questions were referred under section 66(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Sikri J. The following three questions were referred under section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 Whether there was any material before the Tribunal for the finding that neither of the two amounts of Rs. 3,25,000 and Rs. 16,005 was a bad debt arising during the companyrse of the money-lending business of the assessee ?

facts.text: Assessment year in question is 1942-43 and relevant accounting year is Samvat year 1997-98 corresponding to October 1941.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment year in question is 1942-43 and the relevant accounting year is Samvat year 1997-98, companyresponding to October 1941.

facts.text: Appellant B. Seth Champa Lal Ram Swarup referred to as assessee was a joint Hindu family headed by karta Moti Lal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, B. Seth Champa Lal Ram Swarup  hereinafter referred to as the assessee , was a joint Hindu family headed by the karta, Moti Lal.

facts.text: During the accounting year a sum of Rs. 3,25,000 was due to the assessee from Shanti Lal proprietor of M/s. Amolakchand Mewaram.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year a sum of Rs. 3,25,000 was due to the assessee from one Shanthi Lal, who carried on business as proprietor of M s. Amolakchand Mewaram.

facts.text: Shanti Lal is the younger brother of Moti Lal and had been taken in adoption by a cousin of Motilal.

anchor.surface_text: Shanti Lal is the younger brother of Moti Lal and had been taken in adoption by a companysin of Motilal.

facts.text: M/s. Amolakchand Mewaram had a current account with the assessee for a number of years with large cash payments on either side.

anchor.surface_text: M s. Amolakchand Mewaram had a current account with the assessee for a number of years in which there were large cash payment on either side.

facts.text: Current account credited with sales of cotton and other goods made by assessee on behalf of M/s Amolakchand Mewaram, debited with speculation losses and differences paid by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: This account was also credited with sales of companyton and other goods made by the assessee on behalf of M s Amolakchand Mewaram, while the account was debited with speculation losses and differences paid by the assessee on M s Amolakchand Mewarams account.

facts.text: In Samvat year 1987-88 ending November 1931 advances to M/s. Amolakchand Mewaram rose to Rs. 11 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: In Samvat year 1987-88, the year ending November, 1931, advances made to M s. Amolakchand Mewaram in this account rose up to Rs. 11 lakhs.

facts.text: During Samvat 1987-88 assessee took mortgage of immovable property of M/s. Amolakchand Mewaram for Rs. 3 lakhs credited to current account debited to new Amolakchand Mewaram Mortgage account.

anchor.surface_text: During this year the assessee took a mortgage of the immovable property of M s. Amolakchand Mewaram for Rs. 3 lakhs and credited the amount to the current account, the debit being given to a new account styled Amolakchand Mewaram Mortgage account.

facts.text: In next accounting year assessee took over interest of M/s. Amolakchand Mewaram in managing agency of Edward Mills Limited and shares for Rs. 4,50,000 credit to current account.

anchor.surface_text: In the next accounting year the assessee took over the interest of M s. Amolakchand Mewaram in the managing agency of the Edward Mills Limited and also the shares of the Edward Mills Limited for Rs. 4,50,000 for which also a credit was given in the current account.

facts.text: On November 3, 1932 assessee obtained pro-note from M/s. Amolakchand Mewaram for Rs. 3,25,000 crediting current account debiting new pro-note account.

anchor.surface_text: In the same year on November 3, 1932, the assessee also obtained a pro-note from M s. Amolakchand Mewaram for Rs. 3,25,000 crediting the amount to the current account, the debit for which given to a new account styled Amolakchand Mewaram pro-note account.

facts.text: After adjustments current account left with debit balance of Rs. 25,626 thereafter only petty transactions and adjustments.

anchor.surface_text: After these adjustments the current account was left with a debit balance of Rs. 25,626. Thereafter, there were only petty transactions and adjustments.

facts.text: No interest charged on Amolakchand Mewaram Mortgage account and Amolakchand Mewaram pro-note account.

anchor.surface_text: The two new accounts, Amolakchand Mewaram Mortgage account and Amolakchand Mewaram pro-note account had been carried forward from year to year but numberinterest had been charged on these accounts.

facts.text: Assessee adjudged insolvent by Bombay High Court in July 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was adjustified insolvent by the Bombay High Court in July, 1938.

facts.text: Adjudication order annulled on April 15, 1941 by Bombay High Court after scheme of composition sanctioned.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, a scheme of companyposition was sanctioned by the same High Court and the adjudication order was unnulled on April 15, 1941.

facts.text: Rs. 16,005 due from Mansukh Lal Panthu Lal.

anchor.surface_text: The facts relating to the second debt of Rs. 16,005 were these. This amount was due from one Mansukh Lal Panthu Lal.

facts.text: Decree obtained by assessee against Mansukh Lal Panthu Lal from Bombay High Court in 1932.

anchor.surface_text: A decree from the Bombay High Court was obtained by the assessee against the debtor in 1932.

facts.text: No effort made to execute the decree against Mansukh Lal Panthu Lal.

anchor.surface_text: The decree was executable for 12 years, but as a matter of fact numbereffort was made to execute the decree and to recover this amount.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that the money was not advanced to Amolakchand Mewaram in course of money-lending business.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, the Appellate Tribunal held that the money was number advanced to the firm Amolakchand Mewaram in the companyrse of money lending business.

facts.text: Tribunal held debt of Rs. 3,25,000 became bad long ago and Rs. 16,005 not advanced in money-lending business and bad prior to year of account.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that the debt of Rs. 3,25,000 became bad long ago. Regarding the bad debt of Rs. 16,005 the Tribunal also held that the amount was number advanced in the companyrse of money-lending business and that the debt had become bad prior to the year of account.

facts.text: High Court answered all three questions against the assessee in favour of department.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered all the three questions against the assessee and in favour of the department.

facts.text: Assessee obtained special leave and appeal is before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee having obtained special leave, the appeal is number before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds there was material for Tribunal to conclude debts became bad prior to year of account.

anchor.surface_text: From a perusal of the findings of the Tribunal and the reasoning of the High Court it is quite clear that there was material for the Tribunal to have companye to the companyclusion that the two debts had become bad prior to the year of account.

facts.text: Pro-note for Rs. 3,25,000 taken on 3rd November 1932.

anchor.surface_text: In order to succeed in claiming that a debt as become bad it is incumbent upon the assessee to establish that the debt was good immediately at the companymencement of the relevant year of account and that it had become bad during the year of account. In the present case the pro-note for Rs. 3,25,000 was taken as far back as the 3rd November, 1932

facts.text: No interest charged and no legal steps taken to recover Rs. 3,25,000 during decade to 1941.

anchor.surface_text: and the assessee is claiming it as bad in the year ending October, 1941, i.e., almost after a decade. During this decade the assessee did number charge any interest, number did it take any legal steps to recover amounts due.

facts.text: Suit against Baij Nath Gauri Dutt decided by Civil Judge Mathura on 29th March 1940 against debtor.

anchor.surface_text: but most of those expectations were shattered long before the relevant year of account. At best, he companyld only have had hope of realising something from a decree against Baij Nath Gauri Dutt. But even that suit was decided by the Civil Judge of Mathura on the 29th March, 1940, against him.

facts.text: No steps taken to execute decree of 1932 for Rs. 16,005.

anchor.surface_text: Although decree was obtained by the assessee against the debtor in 1932, numbersteps were taken to execute the decree.

facts.text: Last asset card of East India Cotton Association taken over for Rs. 20,000 in Samvat year 1994-95.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee purchased Amolakchand Mewarams card of the East India Cotton Association for a sum of Rs. 20,000 resulting in a credit balance in favour of M s Amolakchand Mewaram of Rs. 11,253.

facts.text: Interest charged on current account up to Samvat year 1988-89 only.

anchor.surface_text: In the current account, Interest had been charged up to the Samvat year 1988-89  1931-32  only and number thereafter.

facts.text: At commencement of Samvat year 1994-95 current account debit balance Rs. 9,017.

anchor.surface_text: At the companymencement of the Samvat year 1994-95, there was a debit balance of Rs. 9,017.
